title: Kening Jiang
text:
Welcome!
Thanks for stopping by my site!
My name is Kening Jiang, a PhD student in Epidemiology at Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health.

title: Kening Jiang
text: Kening Jiang is a 3rd year PhD student in Epidemiology of Aging. She received her MHS degree in Epidemiology from Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health and previously worked as a biostatistician at the Johns Hopkins Cochlear Center for Hearing and Public Health. She is interested in studying the underlying mechanisms of cognitive aging, especially how potentially modifiable factors including sensory loss and sleep disturbances contribute to cognitive decline and dementia among older adults.

title: Research question
text:
Research question
To describe and compare the Measles, Mumps, and Rubella (MMR) vaccination rates and overall vaccination rates among public and private schools in California and Ohio


Why vaccinating children is important
 From: Center for Disease Control and Prevention


Intended audience
Public health practitioners, schools, and parents in California and Ohio


Original data
Immunization rate data for schools in the US, as compiled by The Wall Street Journal. Modified dataset was included in TidyTuesday.


Data dictionary
https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/blob/master/data/2020/2020-02-25/readme.md#data-dictionary


Data loading


Show the code
# Load the packages
library("tidyverse")
library("tidytuesdayR")
library("here")

# tests if a directory named "data" exists locally
if (!dir.exists(here("data"))) {
    dir.create(here("data"))
}

if (!file.exists(here("data", "tuesdata_measles.RDS"))) {
    tuesdata <- tidytuesdayR::tt_load("2020-02-25")

# save the files to RDS objects
    saveRDS(tuesdata$measles, file = here("data", "tuesdata_measles.RDS"))
}

# Load the datasets
measles <- readRDS(here("data", "tuesdata_measles.RDS"))




Data wrangling


Show the code
# Clean the original measles dataset
measles_clean<- 
  measles %>%
  mutate(type = replace(type, which(is.na(type)), "Other")) %>%
  filter(mmr>=0) %>%
  filter(overall>=0) %>%
  select(-c('xrel','xmed', 'xper','lat','lng')) %>%
  filter(state=="California" | state=="Ohio")

# Create a summary dataset from the cleaned dataset
measles_summary <- 
  measles_clean %>%
  group_by(state, type)  %>%
  summarize (
             n=n(),
             mean_mmr = mean(mmr),
             min_mmr = min(mmr),
             max_mmr = max(mmr),
             mean_overall = mean(overall),
             min_overall = min(overall),
             max_overall = max(overall)
             )








Pay Attention



Substantial missingness of variables like school type. Only California and Ohio were analyzed due to relatively complete data.




Figure 1. Number of public and private schools in California and Ohio


Show the code
# Include a margin summary table
knitr::kable(
  measles_summary[1:4, 1:3]
)






state
type
n




California
Private
1398


California
Public
12826


Ohio
Private
839


Ohio
Public
2078






Show the code
# Define a custom theme to start with
custom_theme <- theme(
  panel.background = element_blank(),
  axis.ticks = element_blank(),
  axis.title = element_text(size=14, face="bold"),
  axis.line = element_line(size = 0.5),
  plot.title = element_text(color="black", size=18, face="bold", hjust=0.5),
)

figure1 <- ggplot(data=measles_summary, aes(x=state, y=n, fill=type)) +
           # Add stacked bar plot
           geom_bar(stat="identity") +
           scale_fill_manual(name = "School type",
                             values=c("#E1BE6A", "#5D3A9B"),
                             labels = c("Private", "Public")) +
           # Modify the labels for axes
           scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 15000), breaks = seq(0, 15000, 3000)) +
           # Add labels
           labs(x="State",
                y="Number of schools",
                title="Number of public and private schools in California and Ohio",
                subtitle = "A much higher number of public schools than private schools",
                caption = "Kening Jiang") +
           # Modify the theme
           custom_theme +
                 theme(axis.text.x=element_text(size=12),
                       axis.text.y=element_text(size=14),
                       legend.text = element_text(size = 12),
                       legend.title=element_text(size=14, face="bold"),
                       plot.subtitle=element_text(size=14, hjust=0.5),
                       legend.box.background = element_rect(),
                       legend.box.margin = margin(5,5,5,5),
                       strip.text.x = element_text(size = 14, face="bold"),
                       strip.background = element_rect(fill="#D3E1D0"),
                       plot.caption = element_text(size=14)
                 )
# Display the plot
figure1 









Figure 2. Distribution of Measles, Mumps, and Rubella (MMR) vaccination rate by school type in California and Ohio


Show the code
Figure2 <- ggplot(measles_clean, aes(x=type, y=mmr, color=type)) +
           # Add box plot
           geom_boxplot() +
           stat_summary(fun.y=mean, geom="point", shape=23, size=4) +
           # Stratify the plot by state
           facet_wrap(~ state, ncol=2) +
           scale_color_manual(name = "School type",
                             values=c("#E1BE6A", "#5D3A9B"),
                             labels = c("Private", "Public")) +
           # Modify the labels for axes
           scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 100), breaks = seq(0, 100, 10)) +
           # Add labels
           labs(x="Shool type",
                y="MMR vaccination rate",
                title="Distribution of MMR vaccination rate by school type in California and Ohio",
                subtitle = "Most schools have MMR vaccination rate above 90% \n
                            Overall similar patterns in California and Ohio",
                caption = "Kening Jiang") +
           # Modify the theme
           custom_theme +
                 theme(axis.text.x=element_text(size=12),
                       axis.text.y=element_text(size=14),
                       legend.text = element_text(size = 12),
                       legend.title=element_text(size=14, face="bold"),
                       plot.subtitle=element_text(size=14, hjust=0.5),
                       legend.box.background = element_rect(),
                       legend.box.margin = margin(5,5,5,5),
                       strip.text.x = element_text(size = 14, face="bold"),
                       strip.background = element_rect(fill="#D3E1D0"),
                       plot.caption = element_text(size=14)
                 )
# Display the plot
Figure2 









Figure 3. Distribution of overall vaccination rate by school type in California and Ohio


Show the code
Figure3 <- ggplot(measles_clean, aes(x=type, y=overall, color=type)) +
           # Add box plot
           geom_boxplot() +
           stat_summary(fun.y=mean, geom="point", shape=23, size=4) +
           # Stratify the plot by state
           facet_wrap(~ state, ncol=2) +
           scale_color_manual(name = "School type",
                             values=c("#E1BE6A", "#5D3A9B"),
                             labels = c("Private", "Public")) +
           # Modify the labels for axes
           scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 100), breaks = seq(0, 100, 10)) +
           # Add labels
           labs(x="Shool type",
                y="Overall vaccination rate",
                title="Distribution of overall vaccination rate by school type in California and Ohio",
                subtitle = "Most schools have overall vaccination rate above 90% \n
                            Overall similar patterns in California and Ohio",
                caption = "Kening Jiang") +
           # Modify the theme
           custom_theme +
                 theme(axis.text.x=element_text(size=12),
                       axis.text.y=element_text(size=14),
                       legend.text = element_text(size = 12),
                       legend.title=element_text(size=14, face="bold"),
                       plot.subtitle=element_text(size=14, hjust=0.5),
                       legend.box.background = element_rect(),
                       legend.box.margin = margin(5,5,5,5),
                       strip.text.x = element_text(size = 14, face="bold"),
                       strip.background = element_rect(fill="#D3E1D0"),
                       plot.caption = element_text(size=14)
                 )
# Display the plot
Figure3 









Figure 4. Comparison of measles, Mumps, and Rubella (MMR) and overall vaccination rate among public schools in California and Ohio


Show the code
Figure4 <- measles_clean %>% filter(type=="Public") %>%
           ggplot(aes(x=mmr, y=overall)) +
           # Add jitter
           geom_jitter(color="#808080") +
           # Add reference line y=x
           geom_abline(size=2) +
           geom_smooth(method='lm', color="#5D3A9B", size=2) +
           facet_wrap(~ state, ncol=2) +
           # Modify the labels for axes
           scale_x_continuous(limits = c(0, 100), breaks = seq(0, 100, 10)) +
           scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 100), breaks = seq(0, 100, 10)) +
           # Add labels
           labs(x="MMR vaccination rate",
                y="Overall vaccination rate",
                title="MMR vs. overall vaccination rate among public schools in California and Ohio",
                subtitle = "Lower MMR vaccination rate than overall vaccination rate",
                caption = "Kening Jiang") +
          # Modify the theme
           custom_theme +
                 theme(axis.text.x=element_text(size=12),
                       axis.text.y=element_text(size=14),
                       legend.text = element_text(size = 12),
                       legend.title=element_text(size=14, face="bold"),
                       plot.subtitle=element_text(size=14, hjust=0.5),
                       legend.box.background = element_rect(),
                       legend.box.margin = margin(5,5,5,5),
                       strip.text.x = element_text(size = 14, face="bold"),
                       strip.background = element_rect(fill="#D3E1D0"),
                       plot.caption = element_text(size=14)
                 )
# Display the plot
Figure4 

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'








A smooth line imposing a linear relationship was fitted, and it was compared to the reference line of y=x.






Caution



Sparse data points when vaccination rates are low.




Figure 5. Comparison of measles, Mumps, and Rubella (MMR) and overall vaccination rate among private schools in California and Ohio‚Äù


Show the code
Figure5 <- measles_clean %>% filter(type=="Private") %>%
           ggplot(aes(x=mmr, y=overall)) +
           # Add jitter
           geom_jitter(color="#808080") +
           # Add reference line y=x
           geom_abline(size=2) +
           geom_smooth(method='lm', color="#5D3A9B", size=2) +
           facet_wrap(~ state, ncol=2) +
           # Modify the labels for axes
           scale_x_continuous(limits = c(0, 100), breaks = seq(0, 100, 10)) +
           scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 100), breaks = seq(0, 100, 10)) +
           # Add labels
           labs(x="MMR vaccination rate",
                y="Overall vaccination rate",
                title="MMR vs. overall vaccination rate among private schools in California and Ohio",
                subtitle = "Lower MMR vaccination rate than overall vaccination rate",
                caption = "Kening Jiang") +
           # Modify the theme
           custom_theme +
                 theme(axis.text.x=element_text(size=12),
                       axis.text.y=element_text(size=14),
                       legend.text = element_text(size = 12),
                       legend.title=element_text(size=14, face="bold"),
                       plot.subtitle=element_text(size=14, hjust=0.5),
                       legend.box.background = element_rect(),
                       legend.box.margin = margin(5,5,5,5),
                       strip.text.x = element_text(size = 14, face="bold"),
                       strip.background = element_rect(fill="#D3E1D0"),
                       plot.caption = element_text(size=14)
                 )
# Display the plot
Figure5 

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'








A smooth line imposing a linear relationship was fitted, and it was compared to the reference line of y=x.






Caution



Sparse data points when vaccination rates are low.




Summary
This data analysis project used measles and overall vaccination rate data in California and Ohio, originally compiled by The Wall Street Journal. We described and compared measles and overall vaccination rates by school type in both states. A total of 12,826 public schools and 1,398 private schools in California and 2,078 public schools and 839 private schools were included in the analysis. Most schools have measles and overall vaccination rates above 90% and similar patterns were observed for both California and Ohio. The measles vaccination rates were slightly lower than the overall vaccination rates, especially when the vaccination rates were low. However, with high missingness, further analysis is needed.


Functions used

dplyr or tidyr

mutate()
filter()
select()
group_by()
summarise()

ggplot2

geom_bar()
geom_boxplot()
geom_jitter()
geom_smooth()




References


Disease Control, Center for, and Prevention. 2023. ‚ÄúMaking the Vaccine Decision: Addressing Common Concerns.‚Äù https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/parents/why-vaccinate/vaccine-decision.html#:~:text=Because%20a%20baby's%20immune%20system,build%20up%20their%20natural%20defenses.


Jensen, Asger Lundorff, and Mads Kjelgaard‚ÄêHansen. 2006. ‚ÄúMethod Comparison in the Clinical Laboratory.‚Äù Veterinary Clinical Pathology 35 (3): 276‚Äì86.


Journal, The Wallstreet. 2019. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the Measles Vaccination Rate at Your Child‚Äôs School?‚Äù https://www.wsj.com/graphics/school-measles-rate-map/.


McGill, Robert, John W. Tukey, and Wayne A. Larsen. 1978. ‚ÄúVariations of Box Plots.‚Äù The American Statistician 32 (1): 12‚Äì16. https://doi.org/10.2307/2683468.

title: Research question
text:
Research question
To describe and compare the Measles, Mumps, and Rubella (MMR) vaccine rates and overall vaccine rates among public and private schools in California and Ohio


MMR vaccine information







Intended audience
Public health practitioners, schools, and parents in California and Ohio


Original data
Immunization rate data for schools in the US, as compiled by The Wall Street Journal. Modified dataset was included in TidyTuesday.


Data dictionary
https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/blob/master/data/2020/2020-02-25/readme.md#data-dictionary


Data wrangling

# Load the packages
library("tidyverse")
library("tidytuesdayR")
library("here")

# tests if a directory named "data" exists locally
if (!dir.exists(here("data"))) {
    dir.create(here("data"))
}


if (!file.exists(here("data", "tuesdata_measles.RDS"))) {
    tuesdata <- tidytuesdayR::tt_load("2020-02-25")

    # save the files to RDS objects
    saveRDS(tuesdata$measles, file = here("data", "tuesdata_measles.RDS"))
}

# Load the datasets
measles <- readRDS(here("data", "tuesdata_measles.RDS"))


measles_clean<- 
  measles %>%
  mutate(type = replace(type, which(is.na(type)), "Other")) %>%
  filter(mmr>=0) %>%
  filter(overall>=0) %>%
  select(-c('xrel','xmed', 'xper','lat','lng')) %>%
  filter(state=="California" | state=="Ohio")
    
measles_summary <- 
  measles_clean %>%
  group_by(state, type)  %>%
  summarize (
             mean_mmr = mean(mmr),
             mean_overall = mean(overall),
             n=n()
             )







Pay Attention



Schools with missing type are classified as ‚ÄúOther‚Äù



# Define a custom theme to start with
custom_theme <- theme(
  panel.background = element_blank(),
  axis.ticks = element_blank(),
  axis.title = element_text(size=14, face="bold"),
  axis.line = element_line(size = 0.5),
  plot.title = element_text(color="black", size=18, face="bold", hjust=0.5),
)

figure1 <- ggplot(data=measles_summary, aes(x=state, y=n, fill=type)) +
           geom_bar(stat="identity") +
           custom_theme
  
figure1 







Figure2 <- ggplot(measles_clean, aes(x=type, y=mmr)) +
           geom_boxplot() +
           stat_summary(fun.y=mean, geom="point", shape=23, size=4) +
           facet_wrap(~ state, ncol=2) +
           custom_theme

Figure2 







Figure3 <- ggplot(measles_clean, aes(x=type, y=overall)) +
           geom_boxplot() +
           stat_summary(fun.y=mean, geom="point", shape=23, size=4) +
           facet_wrap(~ state, ncol=2) +
           custom_theme

Figure3 







Figure4 <- measles_clean %>% filter(type=="Public") %>%
           ggplot(aes(x=mmr, y=overall)) +
           geom_point() +
           geom_abline() +
           geom_smooth(method='lm') +
           facet_wrap(~ state, ncol=2) +
           custom_theme

Figure4 
`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'







Figure5 <- measles_clean %>% filter(type=="Private") %>%
           ggplot(aes(x=mmr, y=overall)) +
           geom_point() +
           geom_abline() +
           geom_smooth(method='lm') +
           facet_wrap(~ state, ncol=2) +
           custom_theme

Figure5 
`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'
